titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Howard Jones Papers
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:18

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Howard Jones papers consist of correspondence, personal papers, writings, and other documents relating to Jones, his parents, sister Genevieve, and other family members. Present are his essays and speeches on subjects such as birds, medicine, the history of medicine, and the history of Circleville, Ohio, particularly concerning the region's American Indians, in the form of manuscripts, typescripts, and printed ephemera. Business papers include correspondence and documents relating to the Circleville Electric Light and Power Company, organized by Howard Jones in 1891. Also present is material concerning the production and distribution of the Jones family's publication Illustrations of the nests and eggs of birds of Ohio (1879-1886), which featured texts by Howard Jones and ornithological drawings by Genevieve E. Jones, Virginia S. Jones, and Eliza J. Shulze, and was underwritten by Nelson Edward Jones. Series V. contains printed material left after distribution of the publication, which was printed in Cincinnati by Krebs Lithographing Co. (plates) and Robert Clarke & Co. (texts). A small group of papers for Nelson Jones contains some of his writings, press clippings, and biographical sketches of family members including his wife Virginia and daughter Genevieve, as well as two letters discussing the medical treatment of President James A. Garfield shortly before his death. A folder of material for Howard Jones's maternal grandparents Anson and Amy Beckwith Smith contains letters to them in New London, Connecticut, from their two sons, John Robertson Smith and Hamilton Lanphere Smith. Also in the collection are two short runs of amateur periodicals published in Circleville, Ohio.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Howard Jones Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Howard Jones Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Printed works by Jones, including a two-volume set of illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio , also the gift of Eleanor B. Jones in 1963, were cataloged separately. One set of illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio , still in parts in original wrappers, as sold to subscriber number 26 Edgar A. Mearns, was given to the library by William Robertson Coe in 1948.

bioghist.head: Howard Jones (1853-1945)
bioghist.p: Howard Edward Jones was born in Cleveland, Ohio, on August 24, 1853, the son of Dr. Nelson E. Jones (1821-1901) and Virginia Smith Jones (1826-1906). Raised in Circleville, Ohio, he received two degrees from Hobart College in Geneva, New York (BA 1875, MA 1878), where he had helped to organize the college's natural history collections. In 1876 Jones received an MD degree from Ohio Medical College in Cincinnati, followed by studies at the College of Physicians and Surgeons (now Columbia University) in New York City. He married Mary MacMullin in 1882, and practiced medicine in Circleville from the late 1870s until his death there on December 12, 1945. Outside his chosen profession, Jones was a noted naturalist and local historian who spoke and published about regional history, particularly focusing on American Indians, and founded the Ohio History Day Association with his wife Mary in 1926. Jones wrote , a history of Circleville, and an historical novel, The Tragedy of La Belle Riviere, as well as a number of articles on birds, medicine, medical history, and other topics. As a child, Jones had learned from his mother that her brother, Hamilton L. Smith, was the first daguerreotypist in Ohio; in his research he found instead that Smith had been the first American to patent the process of making photographs on japanned metal surfaces, later known as tintypes, in 1856. Also civic-minded, Jones was the president of the Circleville Light and Power Company, which he organized in 1891 to bring electric lights to Circleville's streets and merchants.

In 1878 Howard Jones's sister Genevieve (1847-1879) and her friend Eliza Jane Shulze began a project to illustrate the nests and eggs of local birds in the fashion of John James Audubon's work Birds of America . Howard Jones agreed to collect the required specimens and to write the accompanying texts, and the two women, both amateur artists, drew images of the specimens directly on lithographic stones and hand-colored the resulting prints. Their limited-edition publication, titled Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio , was issued to subscribers in twenty-three parts between 1879 and 1886, with the printing done in Cincinnati by the Krebs Lithographing Co. (plates) and Robert Clarke & Co. (texts); production costs were underwritten by Nelson Jones. When Genevieve Jones died from typhoid fever one month after Part I was issued, her mother Virginia, also an untrained artist, stepped in to complete the illustrations, hiring three young women, including Josephine Klippart (1848-1936), to assist with coloring the plates. The publication was heralded by contemporary ornithologists for its fidelity to nature, with favorable comparisons made to Audubon's work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Howard Jones Papers contains correspondence, personal papers, writings, research material, and some business papers, the latter concerning the Circleville Light and Power Company, and the Jones family's publication Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio . Also present are some family papers, in particular correspondence and writings of Jones's father Nelson E. Jones, and letters to his material grandparents Anson and Amy Beckwith Smith from their sons. While the papers touch of many aspects of Howard Jones's life, they primarily document the family's production and distribution of their masterwork Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio from its beginning in 1878 through the mid-twentieth century.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence and Personal Papers, 1860-1946. II. Writings, 1870-1939. III. Circleville Light and Power Company, 1856-1917. IV. Family Papers, 1835-1951. Series V. Printed Material from Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio , 1878-1888.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Family Correspondence; General Correspondence; and Personal Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Family Correspondence holds largely two-way correspondence between Jones and his sister, wife, parents, son-in-law, and a few other relatives, some of which was exchanged while Jones was a student at Hobart College.

The General Correspondence holds letters on a variety of topics, including Jones's local history research and his search for information on his uncle Hamilton Lanphere Smith. The earliest letters in the series are personal letters from Jones's college friends, but the bulk of his correspondence concerns his twentieth-century distribution of and census of copies of Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio . Additional and earlier material related to that publication project, including contracts, invoices, and correspondence, is filed in Series IV, Family Papers.
Personal Papers and Research Material holds miscellaneous items including ephemera from Jones's college days, two photographs of him, and biographical material.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contains material on the founding of Berger Hospital

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contains one carte-de-visite and one cabinet portrait of Jones

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into three subseries: Local History, Medicine/Medical History, and Other Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains essays, articles, and speeches by Howard Jones, primarily in the form of autograph manuscripts and typescripts, but with some printed items (pamphlets, tearsheets, and clippings) as well. Titles in quotes were assigned by Jones. The third subseries holds miscellaneous essays and speeches on topics such as fox squirrels, Christianity, collie dogs, fish, and dreams, and some of his college research papers and notes. Eleven folders hold various essays on birds and his "A Key for the Identification of the Nests and Eggs of Our Common Birds," which was extracted from his work illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio .
Published writings by Jones, including titles with manuscripts found here, are in the printed collection and cataloged in Orbis

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes autobiographical sketch with portrait of Jones, and a folder of photographs of buildings and scenes in Circleville

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records contain correspondence, prospectuses (typed and printed), agreements, contracts, statements, newspaper clippings, legal papers, and other documents regarding the organization and administration of the utility, and includes some material related to other Ohio utilities. The earliest document in the series is an ordinance regarding the Urbana (Ohio) Gass [sic] Light and Coke Company, dating from 1856. Also here is a group of filled-in forms for a service survey of electric companies around the state of Ohio that Jones conducted in 1899.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into three subseries: Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio ; N. E. Jones Papers; and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains material related to Howard Jones's parents, sister, grandfather, and uncles, and holds the earliest correspondence, contracts, subscription lists, and other documents regarding the family's production and publication of Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio ; additional correspondence between Howard Jones and libraries can be found in Series I. A small group of papers for N. E. Jones contains some of his writings, press clippings, and biographical sketches of family members including his wife Virginia and daughter Genevieve. Also here is a letter to Jones from Dr. Jedediah H. Baxter discussing the medical care of President James A. Garfield before he died, with a second letter carrying an endorsement from Garfield's widow Lucretia.

The Anson Smith folder contains letters to him in New London, Connecticut, from his two sons, John Robertson Smith and Hamilton Lanphere Smith, the brothers of Virginia Smith Jones and both students at Yale College in the mid-1830s; it also holds typed copies of a poem by J. R. Smith.

Filed at the end are runs of two amateur publications, "The Buckeye" newspaper, and "The Pickaway Magazine"; the former was published by Samuel MacMullin, and the latter by Lloyd Jonnes [sic], both relatives of Howard Jones.

did.unittitle: Printed Material from Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds the prospectus sets, and extra lithographed plates and printed text pages remaining with the Jones family after they had completed the distributed their publication Illustrations of the Nests and Eggs of Birds of Ohio . It contains variant wrappers, partial compiled sets of plates and text pages, multiple copies of uncolored plates and text pages, and a group (Box 34) of hand-colored plates in various states, some with manuscript color notations.
